stories.title: 11-year-old discovers ancient turtle fossil on BLM land
stories.summary: An 11-year-old named Touren Pope made an incredible discovery while rockhounding in southwest Wyoming: a fossilized turtle shell dating back nearly 48 million years! This remarkable find not only highlights the rich prehistoric life of the Greater Green River Basin but also showcases the importance of exploration and curiosity in our natural world. Touren's keen eye and adventurous spirit turned a routine outing into a significant archaeological moment, reminding us that history is often just beneath our feet.

stories.title: Is being virtuous good for you – or just people around you? A study suggests traits like compassion may support your own well-being
stories.summary: New research suggests that virtues like compassion and patience not only benefit those around us but also enhance our own well-being. This study challenges the long-held belief that being virtuous is solely for the benefit of others, revealing that practicing kindness can lead to greater happiness for ourselves. By examining daily moments of virtue, the researchers found that embracing these traits can create a positive feedback loop, enriching both our lives and the lives of those we touch.

stories.title: Teacher shocked as he's presented with £94,000 supercar outside school
stories.summary: Jeff Taylor, a dedicated teacher from Eastbourne, received the surprise of a lifetime when he won a £94,000 supercar just weeks after losing his own car in an accident. The unexpected gift, delivered by an online competition firm, left him in shock and surrounded by his colleagues. This delightful twist of fate not only replaced his lost vehicle but also brought joy and excitement to his school community, proving that sometimes luck can turn around just when you need it.

stories.title: Snowplow driver saves stranded motorist in Indianapolis
stories.summary: In a heartwarming act of community spirit, snowplow driver Tony Odom came to the rescue of Jose Trejo, who was stranded in heavy snowfall in Indianapolis. After being flagged down, Odom not only helped Trejo get his car unstuck but also assisted several others in the neighborhood. This story highlights the power of neighbors helping neighbors during tough times, reminding us that kindness and support can shine through even the harshest weather.

stories.title: Nelson donates kidney to cousin: ‘Huge gift’
stories.summary: Lacey Nelson made a life-changing decision when she donated a kidney to her cousin, Max Amsden, who was facing end-stage kidney failure. Despite not having seen him for years, Lacey’s willingness to help demonstrates the power of family bonds and the incredible impact of selfless acts. Her journey from blood donation to organ donation showcases the profound generosity that can exist within families, reminding us of the importance of connection and support in times of need.

stories.title: Otter Tail County appraiser commended for compassionate care during crisis
stories.summary: Todd Finkelson, an appraiser in Otter Tail County, displayed remarkable compassion and quick thinking when he intervened in a potential crisis during a routine property visit. By offering support to a distressed individual and contacting law enforcement, Todd played a crucial role in preventing a tragedy. His actions not only saved a life but also exemplified the profound impact one person can have in a moment of need, proving that kindness and awareness can make all the difference.

stories.title: Blue Spring State Park proves accessibility belongs in nature
stories.summary: A recent 'rolling hike' at Blue Spring State Park allowed Mitch Geier, a double amputee, to reconnect with nature alongside his family. Thanks to all-terrain chairs provided by the park, Mitch was able to experience the outdoors in a way he never thought possible after his health challenges. This initiative not only transformed Mitch's experience but also highlighted the importance of accessibility in nature, ensuring everyone can enjoy the beauty of the outdoors regardless of their physical limitations.

stories.title: World's oldest known rock art predates modern humans' entrance into Europe — and it was found in an Indonesian cave
stories.summary: Scientists have uncovered the world's oldest known rock art, a hand stencil dating back at least 67,800 years, in a cave in Indonesia. This groundbreaking discovery not only provides insight into the early presence of modern humans in the region but also enriches our understanding of human creativity and expression long before recorded history. As researchers continue to explore these ancient sites, we gain a deeper appreciation for the artistic capabilities of our ancestors.

stories.title: Downtown church takes rare step amid cold, opens doors as overnight shelter
stories.summary: In a remarkable act of compassion, St. Paul’s Cathedral in London opened its doors as an overnight shelter for the homeless during a severe cold snap. This historic cathedral, known for its community outreach, welcomed around 50 individuals seeking warmth and safety, showcasing the power of community support in times of need.

stories.title: Huntington’s Disease Has Local Man Walking/Running Causeway Bridge Daily
stories.summary: Rip Wagner, diagnosed with Huntington's disease, has turned his daily walks and runs across the Causeway Bridge into a powerful testament to resilience. By maintaining a rigorous exercise routine, he actively combats the progression of his condition while inspiring others with his determination. Rip's journey showcases the importance of movement and positivity in facing life's challenges, reminding us that every step forward is a victory worth celebrating.

stories.title: Local students join forces to combat hunger in Georgia and Kentucky
stories.summary: Students from Lanier High School in Georgia are uniting to combat hunger by partnering with Meals to Missions to raise funds for 10,000 nutritious meals. This initiative not only addresses food insecurity locally but also reaches underserved communities in Kentucky, demonstrating the impact of youth-led efforts in making a difference.

stories.title: Heroic Central New York Police Officer Getting National Attention
stories.summary: Officer Jamie Pastorello from Syracuse has captured hearts with his compassionate act of helping a woman struggling with groceries in freezing weather. This simple gesture led to a community outpouring of support for Rhea Holmes, who had been living in difficult circumstances. The bond formed between the officer and Rhea not only transformed her life but also highlighted the profound impact of empathy and kindness, proving that even small actions can lead to significant change.

stories.title: Orlando VA Program Uses Dungeons & Dragons to Support Veteran Wellness
stories.summary: At the Orlando VA Healthcare System, veterans are finding healing and connection through tabletop role-playing games like Dungeons & Dragons. The REVEAL Program, led by Navy Veteran Victor Mitchell, uses gaming to foster teamwork and emotional wellness, proving that creativity can be a powerful tool for overcoming trauma and isolation.

stories.title: AI predicts future disease risk using sleep patterns
stories.summary: Stanford researchers have developed an innovative AI model called SleepFM that predicts the risk of over 130 diseases based on sleep patterns. By analyzing extensive sleep recordings from thousands of participants, this groundbreaking technology offers insights into how sleep impacts overall health, potentially transforming our understanding of wellness and disease prevention.

stories.title: This Minnesota Bar Was Built From 300-Year Old Wood
stories.summary: The Trestle Inn in Minnesota, built from 300-year-old wood salvaged from an abandoned railroad bridge, stands as a testament to sustainable practices and historical preservation. This unique bar not only offers a glimpse into the past but also serves as a gathering place for the community, blending history with modern hospitality.

stories.title: This DIY Genius Has Powered His Entire Home With Old Laptop Batteries Since 2016
stories.summary: A resourceful homeowner has turned e-waste into a sustainable energy solution by powering his entire home with repurposed laptop batteries since 2016. This innovative approach not only showcases creativity and resilience but also highlights the potential of recycling technology to create a greener future.

stories.title: Why simply saying ‘hello’ makes the world better
stories.summary: In a world increasingly dominated by technology, the simple act of greeting someone can foster connection and improve community spirit. A call to revive casual conversations and friendly hellos emphasizes the importance of social interactions in combating loneliness and building a sense of belonging.

stories.title: At 408 mph, this drone has just set a Guinness-certified record and the best part is, it was entirely built in-house using a 3D printer
stories.summary: A father-son duo from South Africa has set a Guinness World Record by creating a 3D-printed quadcopter that reached an astonishing speed of 408 mph. Their achievement illustrates the power of innovation and home-based engineering, proving that extraordinary feats can emerge from creativity and determination.

stories.title: North Carolina Amazon Driver From Charlotte Donates Entire $10,000 Reward to Local Children’s Hospital After Receiving Record Customer Thanks
stories.summary: After being recognized as one of Amazon's most-thanked drivers, Charlotte-based delivery driver GreyIon Anthony made headlines by donating his entire $10,000 reward to a local children's hospital. His selfless act of generosity highlights the impact of kindness and community support, inspiring others to give back.

stories.title: The 40-Year Career that Quietly Helped Redefine an Arkansas Gas Utility
stories.summary: Fred Kirkwood's 40-year career with Arkansas Oklahoma Gas reflects a journey of love and commitment. Choosing a path that allowed him to stay close to his family, Kirkwood's story is a reminder of how personal connections can shape our professional lives and lead to meaningful contributions in our communities.

stories.title: Central Oregon innovator nears launch of flying car
stories.summary: Sam Bousfield's dream of creating a flying car is closer to reality than ever! After nearly two decades of hard work, his company, Samson Sky, is on the brink of launching the Switchblade, a vehicle that can drive on roads and take to the skies. With the first test vehicle under construction and production set to start soon, this innovation could revolutionize travel. Bousfield's commitment to keeping R&D in Central Oregon while expanding globally showcases the potential of local ingenuity in the face of international markets.

stories.title: Uncovering the Extraordinary Life of Joseph Reynolds
stories.summary: The remarkable life of Joseph Reynolds, an Irish revolutionary and veteran, is being brought to light just as Ireland commemorates its revolutionary history. From surviving harsh prison conditions to serving in the U.S. Army during World War II, Reynolds' journey reflects resilience and dedication to multiple causes over decades. His story, researched by his grandniece, highlights not only his personal sacrifices but also the broader impact of historical events on individual lives.

stories.title: Man goes from homelessness to helping
stories.summary: Alexander Amstutz, once homeless, has transformed his life and is now a beacon of hope for fellow veterans as a peer support specialist. At the VA Clinic, he uses his own experiences to guide others through their recovery journeys. This story highlights the power of connection and support in overcoming life's challenges, showing that sometimes the best way to heal is to help others.

stories.title: Columbia Falls runners complete 24-hour run-a-thon to support injured teammate
stories.summary: The Columbia Falls High School cross country team has come together in an inspiring show of support for their injured teammate, Hazel Alexander. They organized a 24-hour run-a-thon to raise funds for her recovery after a serious accident. This event not only showcases their dedication to Hazel but also highlights the strength of community spirit and the lengths friends will go to support one another in tough times.

stories.title: The Artemis 2 Astronauts Will Observe Parts of the Moon Humans Have Never Laid Eyes On
stories.summary: NASA's Artemis 2 mission is set to make history as astronauts prepare to observe parts of the Moon that have never been seen by human eyes. This mission marks the first crewed flight to the Moon in over 50 years, paving the way for future lunar exploration. The crew will not only test spaceflight systems but also conduct groundbreaking scientific research, making this a pivotal moment for space exploration and our understanding of the Moon.

stories.title: Iqaluit students turn science and math into a business
stories.summary: Students at École des Trois-Soleils in Iqaluit are turning their science and math skills into entrepreneurial ventures through their robotics club. By creating and selling 3D-printed products, these young innovators are not only learning valuable skills but also fostering a sense of community and creativity. Their projects, from custom orders to fun designs, showcase the exciting intersection of education and business.

stories.title: Owners of San Francisco restaurants offer housing to employees
stories.summary: In a heartening initiative, the owners of Rich Table in San Francisco are offering housing to their employees. By renting out furnished apartments at reduced rates, they are addressing the housing crisis while showing genuine care for their staff. This thoughtful approach not only supports their employees but also sets a positive example for other businesses in the community.

stories.title: Calf Rescued from Harmony Coast Cliff After Being Missing for Over a Week
stories.summary: A dramatic rescue unfolded on the Harmony Coast when a 5-month-old calf, missing for over a week, was saved from a steep cliff. Thanks to the keen eye of a ranch dog and the swift action of specialized rescue teams, the calf was safely hoisted back to solid ground. This heartening story reminds us of the dedication of rescue teams and the unexpected bonds between animals and their human caretakers.

stories.title: Fall River standout multi-sport athlete has begun the fight of his young life with community support
stories.summary: Wesley Araujo, a talented young athlete from Fall River, is facing a challenging battle against leukemia. The community has rallied around him, creating the #WesStrong movement to raise funds for his medical expenses. This outpouring of support not only highlights the strength of community but also the resilience of a young athlete determined to overcome adversity.

stories.title: Her ancestors were expelled from Spain. Now she’s bringing bagels to Madrid.
stories.summary: Tamara Cohen is bringing a taste of home to Madrid with her bagel restaurant, Mazál, after immigrating through Spain’s Sephardic ancestry law. Her journey from uncertainty to entrepreneurship highlights the power of cultural heritage and the impact of food in bridging communities. As bagels gain popularity in Madrid, Cohen's story is a testament to the resilience and creativity of those who seek to celebrate their roots.

stories.title: From Rescues To Smiles: How Pamela Kramer Glickman Built San Diego’s Beloved Pammy’s Pony Parties Mobile Petting Zoo
stories.summary: Pamela Kramer Glickman has transformed her love for animals into a cherished mobile petting zoo, Pammy’s Pony Parties, in San Diego. Starting with a rescued lamb named Julian, she created a joyful experience for families, bringing education and compassion to birthday parties and community events. Over 15 years, her business has not only provided smiles but also fostered connections between people and animals, making a lasting impact on the community.

stories.title: Neighbors helping neighbors: Friendship Circle volunteers bring warmth in the cold
stories.summary: When temperatures plummeted, the Friendship Circle Café and Bakery sprang into action, organizing volunteers to prepare and deliver hot soup to those in need. Rabbi Levi Stein and his team worked tirelessly to ensure that isolated individuals received nourishment and warmth during the harsh winter. This initiative highlights the power of community support and the importance of looking out for one another, especially in challenging times.

stories.title: Could a drug slow aging? UW-Madison researchers seek answers in trial
stories.summary: Researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison are exploring whether the drug rapamycin, originally developed for organ transplant patients, could slow aging in humans. With promising results in animals, the team is conducting a clinical trial to determine its effects on human longevity. This study could pave the way for groundbreaking advancements in health and aging, offering hope for improved quality of life as we grow older.

stories.title: St.Landry Parish warming shelter offers hope amid freeze
stories.summary: In St. Landry Parish, a warming shelter has opened its doors to provide refuge for those affected by freezing temperatures. Local leaders and volunteers are working tirelessly to ensure that everyone has a safe place to stay, complete with warm meals and beds. This initiative highlights the community's compassion and commitment to supporting its most vulnerable members during harsh weather conditions.

stories.title: Utah man with rare facial condition sees his life story told on the big screen
stories.summary: Ben Kjar's inspiring journey is now captured on the big screen in the documentary 'STANDOUT: The Ben Kjar Story.' Born with Crouzon Syndrome, Kjar faced bullying and adversity but transformed his challenges into motivation, becoming a champion wrestler and a beacon of hope for others. His story, now reaching audiences nationwide, aims to inspire individuals to overcome their own obstacles and pursue greatness.

stories.title: Mason City birthday party turns extra wild after guest wins $100K lottery prize
stories.summary: A birthday party in Mason City turned into an unforgettable celebration when Alyea Carter Greenan scratched off a $100,000 lottery ticket among family members. The joyous moment erupted in cheers and hugs, marking not only a significant win but also a chance to pay off student loans and create lasting memories with loved ones. This delightful surprise adds an extra layer of joy to a family gathering.

stories.title: The Man Who Showed That Faith and Reason Align
stories.summary: A thought-provoking commentary explores the alignment of faith and reason, encouraging readers to find harmony between their spiritual beliefs and rational thought. This piece invites reflection on how these two aspects of life can coexist and enrich one another, offering a fresh perspective on the intersection of spirituality and intellect.

stories.title: Markey study finds targeted radiation therapy can be safely combined with chemotherapy
stories.summary: A groundbreaking study from the University of Kentucky Markey Cancer Center reveals that targeted radiation therapy can be safely combined with chemotherapy for stage IV cancer patients. This innovative approach allows patients to continue their chemotherapy without interruption, potentially improving their outcomes. The research highlights the importance of integrating advanced treatment options to enhance patient care and offers new hope for those battling advanced cancer.

stories.title: 200K bikes, 200K readers: CYCLE rewrites kids’ futures one bike at a time
stories.summary: CYCLE is making a significant impact in Houston by linking literacy growth to the joy of receiving a bicycle. Celebrating the distribution of its 200,000th bike, the organization rewards students in Title I schools for meeting reading goals. This initiative not only promotes literacy but also instills valuable lessons about hard work and achievement, helping to rewrite the futures of countless children.

stories.title: New Redmond Drone Program Is Changing Emergency Response
stories.summary: The Redmond Police Department is enhancing emergency response with its new Drone as First Responder program. The Skydio X10 drone promises faster response times and improved safety for officers and the community. By providing real-time visual information, this innovative technology aims to revolutionize how emergencies are managed, ensuring quicker and more effective responses to critical situations.

stories.title: Omaha native rows solo across Atlantic in World’s Toughest Row
stories.summary: Omaha native Taryn Smith is embarking on a remarkable journey as she rows solo across the Atlantic Ocean in the World’s Toughest Row. After nearly three years of intense training, Smith is competing in this grueling 3,000-mile race from the Canary Islands to Antigua, showcasing her adventurous spirit and determination. With no prior rowing experience, she is not only challenging herself but also advocating for Girls on the Run, inspiring others to embrace their passions and push their limits.

stories.title: Ridiculously Cute Coastal Martens are Secretive, OSU Scientists are Getting to Know Them
stories.summary: Researchers at Oregon State University are uncovering the secrets of the coastal marten, a small carnivore nearly driven to extinction. Using non-invasive methods, they gathered vital data on the marten population and habitat, informing conservation efforts for this threatened species. Their findings emphasize the need for protective measures as climate change and habitat loss pose significant risks to these adorable creatures.

stories.title: FDNY paramedics help deliver baby at Whitehall Ferry Terminal
stories.summary: Two FDNY paramedics made headlines after assisting with the delivery of a baby at the Whitehall Ferry Terminal. Their quick thinking and expertise ensured the safety of both mother and child during an unexpected situation. This incident highlights the dedication and readiness of emergency responders to handle any challenge, reinforcing the importance of community safety and support.

stories.title: Newborn puppies saved after being left in box
stories.summary: Nine newborn puppies were saved by the San Marcos Regional Animal Shelter after being abandoned in a box. Thanks to the quick actions of a good Samaritan and the shelter's dedicated staff, these vulnerable pups received the care they needed. The community's support and collaboration with rescue partners ensured that the puppies were placed in loving foster homes, showcasing the power of compassion in action.

stories.title: Celebrating Evelyn Harris: Her voice filled the room again
stories.summary: The celebration of life for acclaimed singer Evelyn Harris brought together family, friends, and fans to honor her legacy through music. Despite her passing, her recorded voice filled the room, allowing attendees to sing along and remember her contributions to music and activism. This heartfelt gathering exemplified the power of community and the enduring impact of a beloved artist.

stories.title: Oral Surgeon Fixes Smiles, Transforms Lives in Bangladesh
stories.summary: Dr. John Wallace and his team at Smile Bangladesh are changing lives one smile at a time by providing crucial surgeries for children with cleft lips and palates. Operating in a country with limited access to such medical care, Wallace's nonprofit has been transforming lives for over two decades, offering hope and a chance for a better future. Each surgery, costing around $300, not only restores physical appearance but also opens doors to improved nutrition, communication, and social integration.

stories.title: Beloved mini horse missing as community rallies to help
stories.summary: The community has rallied around Kim Sherwood, the owner of a beloved mini horse named Ricky, who went missing after a barn fire. Known for his role as a therapy and educational horse, Ricky has touched many lives. Volunteers are actively searching for him, showcasing the deep connections he has fostered within the community. The outpouring of support highlights the impact one small creature can have on so many.

stories.title: Tiny falcons are helping keep the food supply safe on cherry farms
stories.summary: American kestrels, the smallest falcons, are playing a vital role in protecting cherry farms in northern Michigan. By preying on pests that threaten crops, these birds not only help farmers reduce damage but also lower the risk of food-borne illnesses. New research shows that orchards with kestrels experience significantly less crop damage, demonstrating the beneficial relationship between wildlife and agriculture.

stories.title: Young cancer survivor from Alexandria celebrated New Year’s with surprise Caps tickets
stories.summary: Sutton Bullard, a 7-year-old cancer survivor, celebrated the New Year with surprise tickets to see her favorite hockey team, the Washington Capitals. After completing her chemotherapy, Sutton's dream came true when she not only attended the game but also reunited with goaltender Logan Thompson, who had supported her during her treatment. This heartwarming moment marks a new chapter in Sutton's life, filled with hope and joy.

stories.title: FlashTags Could Revolutionize Livestock Protection In The West
stories.summary: A new technology called FlashTags could revolutionize livestock protection in the West. These motion-activated LED ear tags emit random light patterns to deter predators like wolves and coyotes, reducing conflicts for ranchers. This innovative approach not only protects livestock but also promotes coexistence with wildlife, offering a promising solution to a long-standing issue in farming.
